awd_titl_txt: Advances in Paleomagnetic Field Modeling: How does Earth's dipole grow and decay?
awd_abstract_narration:
Part 1: Studies of the past magnetic field are important to a broad range of the geosciences. The dipole moment is our primary shield against energetic particles in the solar wind, controlling the production of cosmogenic isotopes in the upper atmosphere. Estimates of past dipole moment are used to infer cosmogenic isotope production and hence contribute to proxies for solar flux in paleoclimate studies. They also help inform us about expected hazard levels associated with space weather. The geomagnetic field exhibits large changes on a range of temporal and spatial scales, but the focus here is on the past 100 ka. Time varying representations of the field derived from paleo and archeomagnetic data reveal an overall geographic asymmetry in field structure for the past 10 ky with stronger average fields in the northern hemisphere and more active secular variation in the southern hemisphere. There is a long-term increase in the dipole from about 6000 BC until 300 AD, and one interval exhibiting particularly strong growth corresponds to the rapid appearance of regional spikes in field strength in the Levantine region. Since 300 AD the axial dipole strength has generally declined from its peak of around 120 ZAm2 to the present day value near 80 ZAm2.  The regional extent and impact of the Levantine field spikes has yet to be fully elucidated, and it remains an open question whether similar features occur at other places and times. This proposal has two major goals. The first is to explore the relationship between spike-like behavior, dipole growth, and other field properties. The second is to understand changes that lead to intervals of decreasing dipole moment as is happening today and occurred in more dramatic form during the Laschamp excursion centered about 41 ka.  Results will contribute to numerous areas where general or specific knowledge is needed about the geomagnetic field and its variability on centennial to million year time scales.  Systematic electronic archiving of tools and products in the EarthRef Digital Archive community database will make them useful to other US and international researchers in geo- and paleo-magnetism, and for research and educational purposes at multiple levels. This project will enhance future STEM activities and research through mentoring and training of both graduate and undergraduate students.

Part 2: Careful analysis of data uncertainties and improvements in inversion strategies have resulted in greatly improved time varying global spherical harmonic paleomagnetic field models over the time spans from 0-10 ka and 0-100 ka, These models are limited in local temporal and spatial complexity, and do not capture the full complexity of features such as the Levantine spike. However, robust features in the results indicate they can be used as the basis for hypothesis testing about the dynamic structural evolution of the magnetic field.   Assuming flux spikes originate as small scale but large amplitude changes at the core-mantle boundary allows quantification of the spatial extent over which changes should be visible at Earth's surface. Paleofield models for 0-10 ka and 0-100 ka will be used to explore two periods of change in geomagnetic dipole moment: (i) the dipole moment decay and subsequent recovery in a period of 20 ky surrounding the Laschamp excursion, and (ii) growth in dipole moment from about 6000 BC to 300 AD and transition to the decay seen in the present field.

por.por_cntn:
Broader Impact

Studies of the past magnetic field generated in Earth's liquid outer core are important to a broad range of the geosciences. The dipole moment is our primary shield against energetic particles in the solar wind, controlling the production of cosmogenic isotopes in the upper atmosphere. Estimates of past dipole moment are used to infer cosmogenic isotope production and hence contribute to proxies for solar energy flux in paleoclimate studies. They also help inform us about expected hazard levels associated with space weather. The geomagnetic field exhibits large changes on a range of temporal and spatial scales, but the focus here has been on the past 100 ka.  Our results contribute to numerous areas where general or specific knowledge is needed about the geomagnetic field and its variability on centennial to to hundred thousand year time scales.  Systematic electronic archiving of tools and products in the EarthRef Digital Archive community database make them useful to other US and international researchers in geo- and paleo-magnetism, and for research and educational purposes at multiple levels. This project has enhanced future STEM activities and research through mentoring and training of several graduate and undergraduate students, and has enabled further development of international collaborations with researchers in Germany and the United Kingdom.

Intellectual Merit

This proposal had two major goals related to observed growth and decay of the geomagnetic dipole. The first is to explore the relationship between unusual spike-like behavior, dipole growth, and other field properties. The second is to understand the changes that lead to intervals of decreasing dipole moment as is happening today and occurred in more dramatic form during the Laschamp excursion centered about 41 ka when geomagnetic field strength decreased dramatically and field structure was much more complex than the dipole-dominated field we see today.  Representations of global time variations in paleo-geomagnetic field models for zero to ten thousand years ago and zero to one hundred thousand years ago have provided a new view of how the geomagnetic field has evolved and an unprecedented basis for comparison with the results of numerical dynamo simulations. These models are of course limited in local temporal and spatial complexity, and do not capture the full range of features such as the Levantine spike in geomagnetic field strength which occurred about almost 3000 years ago.   But assuming flux spikes originate as small scale but large amplitude changes at the core-mantle boundary allows quantification of the spatial extent over which changes should be visible at Earth's surface.  This has revealed that spikes must have broad regional extent, and are likely correlated with increases in Earth's overall dipole strength.

Robust features in the global field models also indicate they can be used as the basis for testing hypotheses about the dynamic structural evolution of the magnetic field. A major outcome of this project has been the ability to analyze where the most rapid rates of change occur, and place lower bounds on those rates of change.  The most extreme rates of directional change over the past 100 ka are considerably faster than most existing estimates.  Comparisons with numerical simulations provide support for rates of directional change  up to 10 degree/year typically during times of decreasing field strength, almost 100 times faster than current changes.  Extreme directional changes in simulations have been associated with movement of reversed flux across the surface of Earth's core and tend to occur at low to mid latitudes.  In contrast, extreme variations in field strength typically at higher latitude and appear to be associated with intensification of normal polarity flux patches as they migrate across the core surface. The framework  linking numerical simulations to paleofield models offers new scope for greatly improved understanding dynamics of fluid flow and magnetic filed generation in Earth's liquid outer core.
